comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: This is the armored cruiser USS New York (ACR-2), of Spanish-American War fame, later renamed the USS Saratoga, then the USS Rochester in 1917.

comment.author: 97609500@N00
comment._content: This ship was commissioned as New York (ACR-2) in 1893. She was renamed Saratoga in 1911 to make the name New York available for BB-34. Her name was changed again to Rochester in 1917 to free the name for the cruiser CC-3 which was completed as the second US Navy aircraft carrier CV-3. Rochester was decommissioned in 1933 and remained moored in Subic Bay, Phillipines until she was scuttled in December 1941 to prevent her capture by Japanese forces.

comment.author: 97609500@N00
comment._content: Ah, you got in before me, Mr. T!

comment.author: 37744225@N03
comment._content: Quite cool, this ship supported the fight at the Battle of San Juan Hill, My great great grandfather fought in that battle. 1898 (Michael Deveny, 5th Infantry Division, Cuba-Battle of San Juan Hill)

comment.author: 79459515@N00
comment._content: Rochester still sits in the bottom of Subic Bay, Olongapo, Zambales province, Philippines where diving enthusiasts frequent it.
